title: How to Make Sweet Potato Puree

methods.name: Baking Sweet Potatoes in the Oven

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 425 °F (218 °C).
steps.description: Get the oven warmed up while you start assembling the rest of the ingredients and supplies. Before you start baking, check that the oven rack is moved to the upper-middle position. Since it’s much trickier to make a purée from raw potatoes, be sure to cook the potatoes in some form ahead of time.

steps.headline: Line up 3 pounds (1.4 kg) of sweet potatoes on a lined baking pan.
steps.description: Take your potatoes and spread them apart evenly on a foil-lined baking sheet. Don’t worry about cutting or peeling the potatoes ahead of time—all that matters is that the sweet potatoes are thoroughly and evenly baked. Typically, 1 pound (0.45 kg) of sweet potatoes amounts to 1 cup (240 mL) of puree.

steps.headline: Bake the potatoes for 45 minutes.
steps.description: Place the baking sheet into the oven, making sure that it’s on the upper-middle level of the oven. Next, set the oven timer for 45 minutes and wait for the potatoes to cook. Check on the produce periodically, using the oven light as needed. If the potatoes don’t seem fully cooked, keep them in the oven for another 5-15 minutes. If you want to be certain that the sweet potatoes are cooked, slice one open to check. When you cut into a cooked sweet potato, it should be mushy and easy to scoop out.

steps.headline: Let the sweet potatoes cool for at least 10 minutes.
steps.description: Take the potatoes out of the oven and let them cool completely. You can check them after 10 minutes to see if they've cooled off. Make sure that you can comfortably hold the potatoes in your hands without burning yourself before continuing.

steps.headline: Use a vegetable peeler to remove the skin from the outside of the outside of each potato.
steps.description: Set the peeled potatoes aside in a separate bowl or container as you go. If you want, you can cut the sweet potatoes into smaller pieces so they’ll fit more easily into a blender or food processor. Unlike carrots and other vegetables, you might not be able to peel away the sweet potato in smooth, even cuts.

steps.headline: Wash the sweet potatoes to remove any dirt.
steps.description: Hold each sweet potato under cool running water and scrub it with a hard-bristled brush. Continue scrubbing until any visible sections of dirt or grime are removed. If you’d like, scrub the raw potatoes down with a produce wash.

steps.headline: Peel off all of the raw sweet potatoes.
steps.description: After you’ve rinsed the sweet potatoes one more time, use a vegetable peeler to take off the skin. Don’t worry if the potato skin doesn’t come off smoothly at first. Just focus on continuing around the potato and working your way around as you peel.

steps.headline: Cut the peeled potatoes into 1 inch (2.5 cm) cubes.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife to slice the sweet potatoes into small, evenly sized pieces. Make sure that each chunk is bite-sized, and that there are no visible blemishes on any of the pieces. Set the sweet potato cubes aside in a separate bowl or container as you go. If you see any remaining slivers of peel on the potato, be sure to remove them.

steps.headline: Boil the sweet potato pieces for about 15 minutes.
steps.description: Dump the potato chunks into a medium-sized pot of boiling water. Check that all of the pieces are submerged before setting a timer for 15 minutes. To make the water boil more quickly, try covering the pot with a lid.

steps.headline: Pour out any of the excess water from the boiled potatoes.
steps.description: After the time is up, drain the potatoes over the sink with a metal strainer. Set aside the boiled potato chunks in a bowl or small container once they’ve stopped dripping. Spear one piece of sweet potato with a fork before draining away the boiling water. If the chunk doesn’t seem soft and tender, let the pot boil for a few more minutes.

methods.name: Blending the Cooked Potatoes into Purée

steps.headline: Dump the potatoes into a food processor.
steps.description: Take your chopped or whole potatoes and pour them into a food processor or blender. Arrange the cooked sweet potatoes so that they fit comfortably in the appliance with the lid on. If needed, purée the cooked produce in batches.

steps.headline: Puree the potatoes until they’re a sauce-like consistency.
steps.description: Secure the lid on top of the appliance and hit the purée button to blend the sweet potatoes. Depending on the model of your device, you might not have a specific purée button—in this case, use the blend button, or any other option that seems to liquefy the potatoes. Continue holding down the button until the mixture looks smooth. If you don’t want to run your blender or food processor for long periods of time, feel free to run in it shorter, 5-10 second bursts.

steps.headline: Add 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 mL) of water as needed to thin out the puree.
steps.description: Pause the appliance and pour a little bit of water into the food processor as you purée the sweet potatoes. If the mixture seems especially thick to you, a little bit of water can make it easier for an infant to swallow. You can make the puree more savory by adding 0.5 cups (120 mL) of buttermilk, 0.5 cups (120 mL) of whole milk, 6 tablespoons (89 mL) of butter, and a pinch of salt and pepper. Keep in mind that this purée can only be stored for a few days.

steps.headline: Refrigerate or freeze the puree to keep it fresh.
steps.description: Pour the sweet potato into airtight, BPA-free containers. If you’re planning to use the purée within 3 days, keep it in the refrigerator. If you want to save the mixture for later, feel free to freeze the potato purée for up to 3 months. Whenever you go to thaw out sweet potato purée, place it in your refrigerator the night before you plan on using it.

tyn: Baking Sweet Potatoes in the Oven
Blending the Cooked Potatoes into Purée
text: Baking Sweet Potatoes in the Oven Preheat the oven to 425 °F (218 °C). Get the oven warmed up while you start assembling the rest of the ingredients and supplies. Before you start baking, check that the oven rack is moved to the upper-middle position. Since it’s much trickier to make a purée from raw potatoes, be sure to cook the potatoes in some form ahead of time. Line up 3 pounds (1.4 kg) of sweet potatoes on a lined baking pan. Take your potatoes and spread them apart evenly on a foil-lined baking sheet. Don’t worry about cutting or peeling the potatoes ahead of time—all that matters is that the sweet potatoes are thoroughly and evenly baked. Typically, 1 pound (0.45 kg) of sweet potatoes amounts to 1 cup (240 mL) of puree. Bake the potatoes for 45 minutes. Place the baking sheet into the oven, making sure that it’s on the upper-middle level of the oven. Next, set the oven timer for 45 minutes and wait for the potatoes to cook. Check on the produce periodically, using the oven light as needed. If the potatoes don’t seem fully cooked, keep them in the oven for another 5-15 minutes. If you want to be certain that the sweet potatoes are cooked, slice one open to check. When you cut into a cooked sweet potato, it should be mushy and easy to scoop out. Let the sweet potatoes cool for at least 10 minutes. Take the potatoes out of the oven and let them cool completely. You can check them after 10 minutes to see if they've cooled off. Make sure that you can comfortably hold the potatoes in your hands without burning yourself before continuing. Use a vegetable peeler to remove the skin from the outside of the outside of each potato. Set the peeled potatoes aside in a separate bowl or container as you go. If you want, you can cut the sweet potatoes into smaller pieces so they’ll fit more easily into a blender or food processor. Unlike carrots and other vegetables, you might not be able to peel away the sweet potato in smooth, even cuts. Boiling the Sweet Potatoes Wash the sweet potatoes to remove any dirt. Hold each sweet potato under cool running water and scrub it with a hard-bristled brush. Continue scrubbing until any visible sections of dirt or grime are removed. If you’d like, scrub the raw potatoes down with a produce wash. Peel off all of the raw sweet potatoes. After you’ve rinsed the sweet potatoes one more time, use a vegetable peeler to take off the skin. Don’t worry if the potato skin doesn’t come off smoothly at first. Just focus on continuing around the potato and working your way around as you peel. Cut the peeled potatoes into 1 inch (2.5 cm) cubes. Use a sharp knife to slice the sweet potatoes into small, evenly sized pieces. Make sure that each chunk is bite-sized, and that there are no visible blemishes on any of the pieces. Set the sweet potato cubes aside in a separate bowl or container as you go. If you see any remaining slivers of peel on the potato, be sure to remove them. Boil the sweet potato pieces for about 15 minutes. Dump the potato chunks into a medium-sized pot of boiling water. Check that all of the pieces are submerged before setting a timer for 15 minutes. To make the water boil more quickly, try covering the pot with a lid. Pour out any of the excess water from the boiled potatoes. After the time is up, drain the potatoes over the sink with a metal strainer. Set aside the boiled potato chunks in a bowl or small container once they’ve stopped dripping. Spear one piece of sweet potato with a fork before draining away the boiling water. If the chunk doesn’t seem soft and tender, let the pot boil for a few more minutes. Blending the Cooked Potatoes into Purée Dump the potatoes into a food processor. Take your chopped or whole potatoes and pour them into a food processor or blender. Arrange the cooked sweet potatoes so that they fit comfortably in the appliance with the lid on. If needed, purée the cooked produce in batches. Puree the potatoes until they’re a sauce-like consistency. Secure the lid on top of the appliance and hit the purée button to blend the sweet potatoes. Depending on the model of your device, you might not have a specific purée button—in this case, use the blend button, or any other option that seems to liquefy the potatoes. Continue holding down the button until the mixture looks smooth. If you don’t want to run your blender or food processor for long periods of time, feel free to run in it shorter, 5-10 second bursts. Add 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 mL) of water as needed to thin out the puree. Pause the appliance and pour a little bit of water into the food processor as you purée the sweet potatoes. If the mixture seems especially thick to you, a little bit of water can make it easier for an infant to swallow. You can make the puree more savory by adding 0.5 cups (120 mL) of buttermilk, 0.5 cups (120 mL) of whole milk, 6 tablespoons (89 mL) of butter, and a pinch of salt and pepper. Keep in mind that this purée can only be stored for a few days. Refrigerate or freeze the puree to keep it fresh. Pour the sweet potato into airtight, BPA-free containers. If you’re planning to use the purée within 3 days, keep it in the refrigerator. If you want to save the mixture for later, feel free to freeze the potato purée for up to 3 months. Whenever you go to thaw out sweet potato purée, place it in your refrigerator the night before you plan on using it.
sentences: Baking Sweet Potatoes in the Oven Preheat the oven to 425 °F (218 °C).
Get the oven warmed up while you start assembling the rest of the ingredients and supplies.
Before you start baking, check that the oven rack is moved to the upper-middle position.
Since it’s much trickier to make a purée from raw potatoes, be sure to cook the potatoes in some form ahead of time.
Line up 3 pounds (1.4 kg) of sweet potatoes on a lined baking pan.
Take your potatoes and spread them apart evenly on a foil-lined baking sheet.
Don’t worry about cutting or peeling the potatoes ahead of time—all that matters is that the sweet potatoes are thoroughly and evenly baked.
Typically, 1 pound (0.45 kg) of sweet potatoes amounts to 1 cup (240 mL) of puree.
Bake the potatoes for 45 minutes.
Place the baking sheet into the oven, making sure that it’s on the upper-middle level of the oven.
Next, set the oven timer for 45 minutes and wait for the potatoes to cook.
Check on the produce periodically, using the oven light as needed.
If the potatoes don’t seem fully cooked, keep them in the oven for another 5-15 minutes.
If you want to be certain that the sweet potatoes are cooked, slice one open to check.
When you cut into a cooked sweet potato, it should be mushy and easy to scoop out.
Let the sweet potatoes cool for at least 10 minutes.
Take the potatoes out of the oven and let them cool completely.
You can check them after 10 minutes to see if they've cooled off.
Make sure that you can comfortably hold the potatoes in your hands without burning yourself before continuing.
Use a vegetable peeler to remove the skin from the outside of the outside of each potato.
Set the peeled potatoes aside in a separate bowl or container as you go.
If you want, you can cut the sweet potatoes into smaller pieces so they’ll fit more easily into a blender or food processor.
Unlike carrots and other vegetables, you might not be able to peel away the sweet potato in smooth, even cuts.
Boiling the Sweet Potatoes Wash the sweet potatoes to remove any dirt.
Hold each sweet potato under cool running water and scrub it with a hard-bristled brush.
Continue scrubbing until any visible sections of dirt or grime are removed.
If you’d like, scrub the raw potatoes down with a produce wash. Peel off all of the raw sweet potatoes.
After you’ve rinsed the sweet potatoes one more time, use a vegetable peeler to take off the skin.
Don’t worry if the potato skin doesn’t come off smoothly at first.
Just focus on continuing around the potato and working your way around as you peel.
Cut the peeled potatoes into 1 inch (2.5 cm) cubes.
Use a sharp knife to slice the sweet potatoes into small, evenly sized pieces.
Make sure that each chunk is bite-sized, and that there are no visible blemishes on any of the pieces.
Set the sweet potato cubes aside in a separate bowl or container as you go.
If you see any remaining slivers of peel on the potato, be sure to remove them.
Boil the sweet potato pieces for about 15 minutes.
Dump the potato chunks into a medium-sized pot of boiling water.
Check that all of the pieces are submerged before setting a timer for 15 minutes.
To make the water boil more quickly, try covering the pot with a lid.
Pour out any of the excess water from the boiled potatoes.
After the time is up, drain the potatoes over the sink with a metal strainer.
Set aside the boiled potato chunks in a bowl or small container once they’ve stopped dripping.
Spear one piece of sweet potato with a fork before draining away the boiling water.
If the chunk doesn’t seem soft and tender, let the pot boil for a few more minutes.
Blending the Cooked Potatoes into Purée Dump the potatoes into a food processor.
Take your chopped or whole potatoes and pour them into a food processor or blender.
Arrange the cooked sweet potatoes so that they fit comfortably in the appliance with the lid on.
If needed, purée the cooked produce in batches.
Puree the potatoes until they’re a sauce-like consistency.
Secure the lid on top of the appliance and hit the purée button to blend the sweet potatoes.
Depending on the model of your device, you might not have a specific purée button—in this case, use the blend button, or any other option that seems to liquefy the potatoes.
Continue holding down the button until the mixture looks smooth.
If you don’t want to run your blender or food processor for long periods of time, feel free to run in it shorter, 5-10 second bursts.
Add 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 mL) of water as needed to thin out the puree.
Pause the appliance and pour a little bit of water into the food processor as you purée the sweet potatoes.
If the mixture seems especially thick to you, a little bit of water can make it easier for an infant to swallow.
You can make the puree more savory by adding 0.5 cups (120 mL) of buttermilk, 0.5 cups (120 mL) of whole milk, 6 tablespoons (89 mL) of butter, and a pinch of salt and pepper.
Keep in mind that this purée can only be stored for a few days.
Refrigerate or freeze the puree to keep it fresh.
Pour the sweet potato into airtight, BPA-free containers.
If you’re planning to use the purée within 3 days, keep it in the refrigerator.
If you want to save the mixture for later, feel free to freeze the potato purée for up to 3 months.
Whenever you go to thaw out sweet potato purée, place it in your refrigerator the night before you plan on using it.
